Problem:
Consider a complex function \\( z(t) = x(t) + iy(t) \\) where \\( x(t) \\) and \\( y(t) \\) are real-valued functions governed by the equations \\( \\dot{x} = Ax \\) and \\( \\dot{y} = By \\), A and B are constant matrices. We explore the effect of a linear transformation \\( h(z) = Cz \\), where C is a constant complex matrix, applied at different times.

If at a certain time \\( t_1 \\), a new transformation \\( k(z) = Dz \\) (where D is another constant complex matrix) is applied, will the endpoint \\( z(T) \\) for T > t_1 depend only on A and B and not on C or D?
Explanation: The intervention with \\( k(z) \\) means the behavior of the system is now influenced by D as well as by C. The transformations have cumulative effects and depending on non-commutative properties of matrix multiplication in complex space, the outcome at time T will depend on all matrices A, B, C, and D.
